title: gt crew at fails to detect existing crew session
description:
## Summary
`gt crew at` started a new Claude session instead of attaching to an existing one for the same crew worker.

## Reproduction
1. Have a crew worker (joe) running in gastown/crew/joe (PID 27526 on tty s030)
2. Run `gt crew at` from the same directory (gastown/crew/joe)
3. Expected: Attach to existing session on s030
4. Actual: Started a brand new Claude session (PID 67618 on s026)

## Evidence
```
# Old joe still running:
PID 27526 on s030: /Users/stevey/gt/gastown/crew/joe (started 10:22AM)

# New joe spawned by 'gt crew at':
PID 67618 on s026: /Users/stevey/gt/gastown/crew/joe (started 10:39AM)
```

## Impact
- Duplicate crew workers cause confusion
- User expected to attach to existing session, not spawn a second one
- The original session was still functional (just stuck in feed display)

## Likely cause
`gt crew at` probably doesn't check for running Claude processes in the crew directory before spawning a new one. It should:
1. Check for existing tmux sessions for this crew worker
2. Check for running `claude` processes with cwd matching the crew directory
3. If found, attach to existing session instead of spawning new one
close_reason: Fixed by adding FindSessionByWorkDir() to detect existing Claude sessions in the crew directory before creating a new one

title: Beads epic templates for batch work patterns
description:
Optional: Define templates for common batch work patterns.

## Concept

A template encodes a workflow pattern that can be instantiated as beads:

```yaml
# templates/batch-basic.yaml
name: basic-batch
description: Simple batch work pattern
phases:
  - name: startup
    issues:
      - title: "Verify workers ready"
  - name: working
    # Actual work issues added separately
  - name: cleanup
    issues:
      - title: "Merge all branches"
      - title: "Clean up workers"
      - title: "Report to Mayor"
```

## Usage

```bash
gt spawn --template basic-batch --epic gt-u1j --workers 3
```

Creates beads epic with template phases + actual work from gt-u1j children.

## Decision Point

Templates are OPTIONAL. The core design (beads as state, multi-wave orchestration) works without templates. Templates are sugar for common patterns.

Consider deferring to P3 or dropping entirely if beads epics with dependencies suffice.

## Note

No "swarm IDs" involved - templates just pre-populate epic/issue structure.

title: gt commands should follow .beads/redirect
description:
## Problem

`gt sling` (and likely other gt commands) don't follow the `.beads/redirect` file that `bd` uses to share beads across clones.

This caused confusion during the v0.39.0 release: molecules were poured successfully to mayor/rig's beads (via redirect), but `gt sling` couldn't find them because it was looking in the crew clone's local .beads/.

## Expected Behavior

All `gt` commands that interact with beads should follow the redirect mechanism that `bd` uses.

## Affected Commands (likely)

- `gt sling`
- `gt hook`  
- `gt mol status`
- `gt mol attach`
- Any command that shells out to `bd show` or similar

## Solution

When `gt` needs to find the beads directory, check for `.beads/redirect` and follow it, same as `bd` does.

title: Agent Communication Protocol
description:
Structured mail between agents for coordination.

## Problem
Agents communicate via freeform mail. This works but lacks parseable structure for automated handling.

## Protocols

### Witness to Refinery
- POLECAT_READY: worker X completed, branch ready for merge
- REWORK_COMPLETE: worker Y finished requested rework

### Refinery to Witness  
- MERGE_SUCCESS: worker X merged, can be cleaned up
- MERGE_FAILED: worker X needs rework (reason attached)
- REWORK_REQUEST: please have worker X rebase on current main

### Polecat to Witness
- WORK_COMPLETE: done with assigned issue
- NEED_HELP: stuck, requesting intervention

### Any to Deacon
- ESCALATION: problem requiring Mayor attention

## Mail Format
Subject: [PROTOCOL_TYPE] brief description
Body: Structured YAML or JSON payload

## Success Criteria
- Patrol steps parse protocol messages automatically
- Handlers exist for each protocol type
- Integration test: polecat completes -> witness notifies -> refinery merges -> witness cleans up

Consolidates gt-0qki.

title: mol-deacon-patrol
description:
Mayor's daemon patrol loop.

The Deacon is the Mayor's background process that runs continuously, handling callbacks, monitoring rig health, and performing cleanup. Each patrol cycle runs these steps in sequence, then loops or exits.

## Second-Order Monitoring

Witnesses send WITNESS_PING messages to verify the Deacon is alive. This
prevents the "who watches the watchers" problem - if the Deacon dies,
Witnesses detect it and escalate to the Mayor.

The Deacon's agent bead last_activity timestamp is updated during each patrol
cycle. Witnesses check this timestamp to verify health.

title: mol-polecat-work
description:
Full polecat lifecycle from assignment to decommission.

This proto enables nondeterministic idempotence for polecat work. A polecat that crashes after any step can restart, read its molecule state, and continue from the last completed step. No work is lost.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| issue | Yes | The source issue ID being worked on |

title: Check convoy completion
description:
Check convoy completion status.

Convoys are coordination beads that track multiple issues across rigs. When all tracked issues close, the convoy auto-closes.

**Step 1: Find open convoys**
```bash
bd list --type=convoy --status=open
```

**Step 2: For each open convoy, check tracked issues**
```bash
bd show <convoy-id>
# Look for 'tracks' or 'dependencies' field listing tracked issues
```

**Step 3: If all tracked issues are closed, close the convoy**
```bash
# Check each tracked issue
for issue in tracked_issues:
    bd show <issue-id>
    # If status is open/in_progress, convoy stays open
    # If all are closed (completed, wontfix, etc.), convoy is complete

# Close convoy when all tracked issues are done
bd close <convoy-id> --reason "All tracked issues completed"
```

**Note**: Convoys support cross-prefix tracking (e.g., hq-* convoy can track gt-*, bd-* issues). Use full IDs when checking.

title: Maintain dog pool
description:
Ensure dog pool has available workers for dispatch.

**Step 1: Check dog pool status**
```bash
gt dog status
# Shows idle/working counts
```

**Step 2: Ensure minimum idle dogs**
If idle count is 0 and working count is at capacity, consider spawning:
```bash
# If no idle dogs available
gt dog add <name>
# Names: alpha, bravo, charlie, delta, etc.
```

**Step 3: Retire stale dogs (optional)**
Dogs that have been idle for >24 hours can be removed to save resources:
```bash
gt dog status <name>
# Check last_active timestamp
# If idle > 24h: gt dog remove <name>
```

**Pool sizing guidelines:**
- Minimum: 1 idle dog always available
- Maximum: 4 dogs total (balance resources vs throughput)
- Spawn on demand when pool is empty

**Exit criteria:** Pool has at least 1 idle dog.
close_reason: Dog pool feature not yet implemented (gt dog command unavailable)

title: Burn and respawn or loop
description:
Burn and let daemon respawn, or exit if context high.

Decision point at end of patrol cycle:

If context is LOW:
- Sleep briefly (avoid tight loop)
- Return to inbox-check step

If context is HIGH:
- Write state to persistent storage
- Exit cleanly
- Let the daemon orchestrator respawn a fresh Deacon

The daemon ensures Deacon is always running:
```bash
# Daemon respawns on exit
gt daemon status
```

This enables infinite patrol duration via context-aware respawning.
close_reason: Patrol cycle complete - all 15 steps executed

title: Check Witness and Refinery health
description:
Check Witness and Refinery health for each rig.

**ZFC Principle**: You (Claude) make the judgment call about what is "stuck" or "unresponsive" - there are no hardcoded thresholds in Go. Read the signals, consider context, and decide.

For each rig, run:
```bash
gt witness status <rig>
gt refinery status <rig>
```

**Signals to assess:**

| Component | Healthy Signals | Concerning Signals |
|-----------|-----------------|-------------------|
| Witness | State: running, recent activity | State: not running, no heartbeat |
| Refinery | State: running, queue processing | Queue stuck, merge failures |

**Tracking unresponsive cycles:**

Maintain in your patrol state (persisted across cycles):
```
health_state:
  <rig>:
    witness:
      unresponsive_cycles: 0
      last_seen_healthy: <timestamp>
    refinery:
      unresponsive_cycles: 0
      last_seen_healthy: <timestamp>
```

**Decision matrix** (you decide the thresholds based on context):

| Cycles Unresponsive | Suggested Action |
|---------------------|------------------|
| 1-2 | Note it, check again next cycle |
| 3-4 | Attempt restart: gt witness restart <rig> |
| 5+ | Escalate to Mayor with context |

**Restart commands:**
```bash
gt witness restart <rig>
gt refinery restart <rig>
```

**Escalation:**
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Health: <rig> <component> unresponsive" \
  -m "Component has been unresponsive for N cycles. Restart attempts failed.
      Last healthy: <timestamp>
      Error signals: <details>"
```

Reset unresponsive_cycles to 0 when component responds normally.
close_reason: Witness and Refinery healthy: both running, no issues detected

title: Nudge newly spawned polecats
description:
Nudge newly spawned polecats that are ready for input.

When polecats are spawned, their Claude session takes 10-20 seconds to initialize. The spawn command returns immediately without waiting. This step finds spawned polecats that are now ready and sends them a trigger to start working.

**ZFC-Compliant Observation** (AI observes AI):

```bash
# View pending spawns with captured terminal output
gt deacon pending
```

For each pending session, analyze the captured output:
- Look for Claude's prompt indicator "> " at the start of a line
- If prompt is visible, Claude is ready for input
- Make the judgment call yourself - you're the AI observer

For each ready polecat:
```bash
# 1. Trigger the polecat
gt nudge <session> "Begin."

# 2. Clear from pending list
gt deacon pending <session>
```

This triggers the UserPromptSubmit hook, which injects mail so the polecat sees its assignment.

**Bootstrap mode** (daemon-only, no AI available):
The daemon uses `gt deacon trigger-pending` with regex detection. This ZFC violation is acceptable during cold startup when no AI agent is running yet.

title: Execute registered plugins
description:
Execute registered plugins.

Scan ~/gt/plugins/ for plugin directories. Each plugin has a plugin.md with YAML frontmatter defining its gate (when to run) and instructions (what to do).

See docs/deacon-plugins.md for full documentation.

Gate types:
- cooldown: Time since last run (e.g., 24h)
- cron: Schedule-based (e.g., "0 9 * * *")
- condition: Metric threshold (e.g., wisp count > 50)
- event: Trigger-based (e.g., startup, heartbeat)

For each plugin:
1. Read plugin.md frontmatter to check gate
2. Compare against state.json (last run, etc.)
3. If gate is open, execute the plugin

Plugins marked parallel: true can run concurrently using Task tool subagents. Sequential plugins run one at a time in directory order.

Skip this step if ~/gt/plugins/ does not exist or is empty.

title: Self-review
description:
Review your own changes. Look for:
- Bugs and edge cases
- Style issues
- Missing error handling
- Security concerns

Fix any issues found before proceeding.

title: Handle callbacks from agents
description:
Handle callbacks from agents.

Check the Mayor's inbox for messages from:
- Witnesses reporting polecat status
- Refineries reporting merge results
- Polecats requesting help or escalation
- External triggers (webhooks, timers)

```bash
gt mail inbox
# For each message:
gt mail read <id>
# Handle based on message type
```

**WITNESS_PING**:
Witnesses periodically ping to verify Deacon is alive. Simply acknowledge
and archive - the fact that you're processing mail proves you're running.
Your agent bead last_activity is updated automatically during patrol.
```bash
gt mail archive <message-id>
```

**HELP / Escalation**:
Assess and handle or forward to Mayor.
Archive after handling:
```bash
gt mail archive <message-id>
```

**LIFECYCLE messages**:
Polecats reporting completion, refineries reporting merge results.
Archive after processing:
```bash
gt mail archive <message-id>
```

**DOG_DONE messages**:
Dogs report completion after infrastructure tasks (orphan-scan, session-gc, etc.).
Subject format: `DOG_DONE <hostname>`
Body contains: task name, counts, status.
```bash
# Parse the report, log metrics if needed
gt mail read <id>
# Archive after noting completion
gt mail archive <message-id>
```
Dogs return to idle automatically. The report is informational - no action needed
unless the dog reports errors that require escalation.

Callbacks may spawn new polecats, update issue state, or trigger other actions.

**Hygiene principle**: Archive messages after they're fully processed.
Keep inbox near-empty - only unprocessed items should remain.

title: Rotate logs and prune state
description:
Maintain daemon logs and state files.

**Step 1: Check daemon.log size**
```bash
# Get log file size
ls -la ~/.beads/daemon*.log 2>/dev/null || ls -la ~/gt/.beads/daemon*.log 2>/dev/null
```

If daemon.log exceeds 10MB:
```bash
# Rotate with date suffix and gzip
LOGFILE="$HOME/gt/.beads/daemon.log"
if [ -f "$LOGFILE" ] && [ $(stat -f%z "$LOGFILE" 2>/dev/null || stat -c%s "$LOGFILE") -gt 10485760 ]; then
    DATE=$(date +%Y-%m-%dT%H-%M-%S)
    mv "$LOGFILE" "${LOGFILE%.log}-${DATE}.log"
    gzip "${LOGFILE%.log}-${DATE}.log"
fi
```

**Step 2: Archive old daemon logs**

Clean up daemon logs older than 7 days:
```bash
find ~/gt/.beads/ -name "daemon-*.log.gz" -mtime +7 -delete
```

**Step 3: Prune state.json of dead sessions**

The state.json tracks active sessions. Prune entries for sessions that no longer exist:
```bash
# Check for stale session entries
gt daemon status --json 2>/dev/null
```

If state.json references sessions not in tmux:
- Remove the stale entries
- The daemon's internal cleanup should handle this, but verify

**Note**: Log rotation prevents disk bloat from long-running daemons.
State pruning keeps runtime state accurate.
close_reason: Daemon log at 7MB (under 10MB threshold), no archives over 7 days old

title: Request shutdown
description:
Send shutdown request to Witness.
Wait for termination.

The polecat is now ready to be cleaned up.
Do not exit directly - wait for Witness to kill the session.

title: End-of-cycle inbox hygiene
description:
Verify inbox hygiene before ending patrol cycle.

**Step 1: Check inbox state**
```bash
gt mail inbox
```

Inbox should be EMPTY or contain only just-arrived unprocessed messages.

**Step 2: Archive any remaining processed messages**

All message types should have been archived during inbox-check processing:
- WITNESS_PING → archived after acknowledging
- HELP/Escalation → archived after handling
- LIFECYCLE → archived after processing

If any were missed:
```bash
# For each stale message found:
gt mail archive <message-id>
```

**Goal**: Inbox should have ≤2 active messages at end of cycle.
Deacon mail should flow through quickly - no accumulation.
close_reason: Archived 2 stale messages, inbox now empty

title: Fire notifications
description:
Fire notifications for convoy and cross-rig events.

After convoy completion or cross-rig dependency resolution, notify relevant parties.

**Convoy completion notifications:**
When a convoy closes (all tracked issues done), notify the Overseer:
```bash
# Convoy gt-convoy-xxx just completed
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Convoy complete: <convoy-title>" \
  -m "Convoy <id> has completed. All tracked issues closed.
      Duration: <start to end>
      Issues: <count>

      Summary: <brief description of what was accomplished>"
```

**Cross-rig resolution notifications:**
When a cross-rig dependency resolves, notify the affected rig:
```bash
# Issue bd-xxx closed, unblocking gt-yyy
gt mail send gastown/witness -s "Dependency resolved: <bd-xxx>" \
  -m "External dependency bd-xxx has closed.
      Unblocked: gt-yyy (<title>)
      This issue may now proceed."
```

**Notification targets:**
- Convoy complete → mayor/ (for strategic visibility)
- Cross-rig dep resolved → <rig>/witness (for operational awareness)

Keep notifications brief and actionable. The recipient can run bd show for details.
close_reason: No convoy completions or cross-rig resolutions to notify

title: Check own context limit
description:
Check own context limit.

The Deacon runs in a Claude session with finite context. Check if approaching the limit:

```bash
gt context --usage
```

If context is high (>80%), prepare for handoff:
- Summarize current state
- Note any pending work
- Write handoff to molecule state

This enables the Deacon to burn and respawn cleanly.
close_reason: Context usage command not implemented (gt context --usage unavailable)

title: Resolve external dependencies
description:
Resolve external dependencies across rigs.

When an issue in one rig closes, any dependencies in other rigs should be notified. This enables cross-rig coordination without tight coupling.

**Step 1: Check recent closures from feed**
```bash
gt feed --since 10m --plain | grep "✓"
# Look for recently closed issues
```

**Step 2: For each closed issue, check cross-rig dependents**
```bash
bd show <closed-issue>
# Look at 'blocks' field - these are issues that were waiting on this one
# If any blocked issue is in a different rig/prefix, it may now be unblocked
```

**Step 3: Update blocked status**
For blocked issues in other rigs, the closure should automatically unblock them (beads handles this). But verify:
```bash
bd blocked
# Should no longer show the previously-blocked issue if dependency is met
```

**Cross-rig scenarios:**
- bd-xxx closes → gt-yyy that depended on it is unblocked
- External issue closes → internal convoy step can proceed
- Rig A issue closes → Rig B issue waiting on it proceeds

No manual intervention needed if dependencies are properly tracked - this step just validates the propagation occurred.
close_reason: No cross-rig closures to propagate; blocked issues are correctly tracked

title: Detect cleanup needs
description:
**DETECT ONLY** - Check if cleanup is needed and dispatch to dog.

**Step 1: Preview cleanup needs**
```bash
gt doctor -v
# Check output for issues that need cleaning
```

**Step 2: If cleanup needed, dispatch to dog**
```bash
# Sling session-gc formula to an idle dog
gt sling mol-session-gc deacon/dogs --var mode=conservative
```

**Important:** Do NOT run `gt doctor --fix` inline. Dogs handle cleanup.
The Deacon stays lightweight - detection only.

**Step 3: If nothing to clean**
Skip dispatch - system is healthy.

**Cleanup types (for reference):**
- orphan-sessions: Dead tmux sessions
- orphan-processes: Orphaned Claude processes
- wisp-gc: Old wisps past retention

**Exit criteria:** Session GC dispatched to dog (if needed).
close_reason: Cleanup needed (7 missing agent beads, 4 stale locks, 1 diverged clone) but dog dispatch not available - requires manual 'gt doctor --fix'

title: Evaluate pending async gates
description:
Evaluate pending async gates.

Gates are async coordination primitives that block until conditions are met.
The Deacon is responsible for monitoring gates and closing them when ready.

**Timer gates** (await_type: timer):
Check if elapsed time since creation exceeds the timeout duration.

```bash
# List all open gates
bd gate list --json

# For each timer gate, check if elapsed:
# - CreatedAt + Timeout < Now → gate is ready to close
# - Close with: bd gate close <id> --reason "Timer elapsed"
```

**GitHub gates** (await_type: gh:run, gh:pr) - handled in separate step.

**Human/Mail gates** - require external input, skip here.

After closing a gate, the Waiters field contains mail addresses to notify.
Send a brief notification to each waiter that the gate has cleared.

title: Detect abandoned work
description:
**DETECT ONLY** - Check for orphaned state and dispatch to dog if found.

**Step 1: Quick orphan scan**
```bash
# Check for in_progress issues with dead assignees
bd list --status=in_progress --json | head -20
```

For each in_progress issue, check if assignee session exists:
```bash
tmux has-session -t <session> 2>/dev/null && echo "alive" || echo "orphan"
```

**Step 2: If orphans detected, dispatch to dog**
```bash
# Sling orphan-scan formula to an idle dog
gt sling mol-orphan-scan deacon/dogs --var scope=town
```

**Important:** Do NOT fix orphans inline. Dogs handle recovery.
The Deacon's job is detection and dispatch, not execution.

**Step 3: If no orphans detected**
Skip dispatch - nothing to do.

**Exit criteria:** Orphan scan dispatched to dog (if needed).
close_reason: No in_progress issues found, no orphans to detect

title: Mol Mall: Formula marketplace and aspect composition
description:
## Summary

A marketplace for sharing molecule formulas using GitHub as backend, plus a new
**aspect composition** capability for cooking that allows formulas to be applied
as cross-cutting transformations to existing mols.

## Key Insight

Formulas aren't just standalone workflows—they're **transformations** you can
apply to other mols. This enables patterns like:
- "Apply Rule of Five code review to any coding task"
- "Wrap any epic with security review steps"
- "Add logging/metrics to any patrol molecule"

## Architecture

```
Remote Formulas (GitHub)
        ↓ install
Local Formulas (~/.gt/formulas/ or .beads/formulas/)
        ↓ cook --with
Mols (beads, git-tracked)
        ↓ pour/sling
Execution (ephemeral or tracked)
```

## Formula Types

1. **Standalone** - Complete workflows (mol-polecat-work, mol-deacon-patrol)
2. **Aspects** - Cross-cutting concerns woven into other mols (rule-of-five)
3. **Adapters** - Wrappers that make things runnable

## Aspect Composition (New Cooking Capability)

```bash
bd cook my-epic --with rule-of-five,security-review
```

Aspects declare injection points:

```yaml
# rule-of-five.formula.yaml
kind: aspect
name: rule-of-five
version: 1.2.0

inject_after:
  tag: generates-code  # matches any step with this tag

steps:
  - id: review-correctness
    title: "Review: Correctness"
  - id: review-edge-cases
    title: "Review: Edge Cases"
  - id: review-performance
    title: "Review: Performance"
  - id: review-security
    title: "Review: Security"
  - id: review-maintainability
    title: "Review: Maintainability"
```

Injection modes:
- `inject_after: <step-id or tag>` - insert steps after
- `inject_before: <step-id or tag>` - insert steps before
- `wrap: <step-id or tag>` - insert before AND after
- `replace: <step-id or tag>` - substitute entirely

## The Mall Index

A well-known repo maps short names to full references:

```yaml
# steveyegge/gt-mall/index.yaml
formulas:
  rule-of-five:
    repo: steveyegge/gt-formulas
    path: aspects/rule-of-five.formula.yaml
    version: v1.2.0
    description: "Five-lens code review"
    tags: [review, quality]
```

Commands:
- `gt mol search review` - search the index
- `gt mol install rule-of-five` - fetch from GitHub
- `gt mol install github.com/acme/formulas/custom@v1` - direct URL

## Implementation Phases

### Phase 1: Aspect Composition (Cooking)
- Extend `bd cook` to accept `--with aspect1,aspect2`
- Aspect application during mol generation
- Local aspects in `.beads/formulas/`

### Phase 2: Mall Index
- Create gt-mall repo with index.yaml
- `gt mol search` queries the index
- `gt mol install` fetches and caches formulas

### Phase 3: Publishing
- `gt mol publish` pushes to your formula repo
- PR workflow to add to mall index

### Phase 4: Refinements
- Aspect ordering and conflict detection
- Aspect dependencies (`requires: [other-aspect]`)
- Private formula repos (enterprise)
- Local overrides/forks

## Open Questions

1. **Ordering conflicts**: Two aspects inject after same step—which goes first?
2. **Aspect dependencies**: Aspect A requires aspect B?
3. **Compile-time vs runtime**: Aspects are compile-time (baked into mol).
   Wisps remain runtime (slung dynamically).

## Deferred Until

Gas Town patrols operational. Prerequisites:
- [ ] Patrol system working (Deacon, Witness, Refinery)
- [ ] Basic spawn/work/merge cycle
- [ ] Activity feed showing work progress

Then the mall becomes valuable for sharing patrol customizations.

## Supersedes

This replaces gt-uzf2l which had the original marketplace concept but lacked
the aspect composition insight.

## Related

- Cooking system (bd cook)
- Formula definitions (.formula.yaml)
- Wisp architecture (runtime molecules)
notes: See docs/formula_evolution.md for expanded thinking on: formula resolution hierarchy, combinators (>>, |, wrap, inject, extends), algebraic properties, higher abstractions, Mol Mall registry predictions, distribution scenarios, and open questions. The aspect composition in this design corresponds to the Wrapping (AOP) and Injection combinators in that doc.

title: mol-gastown-boot: Mayor-driven town bootstrap
description:
Mayor bootstraps Gas Town via a verification-gated lifecycle molecule.

## Vision

When user says "boot up gas town", Mayor slings `mol-gastown-boot` and executes it.
Each step has **action + verification** - steps stay open until outcome is confirmed.

## Key Principles

1. **No daemon-based timeouts** - Mayor keeps trying until verified
2. **Verification-gated steps** - Not "command ran" but "outcome confirmed"
3. **gt peek for verification** - Capture session output to detect stalls
4. **gt nudge for recovery** - Reliable message delivery to unstick agents
5. **Parallel where possible** - Witnesses can start in parallel
6. **Ephemeral execution** - Boot is a wisp, squashed to digest

## Proto Catalog

Town maintains a catalog of protos at `~/gt/molecules/`:

```
~/gt/molecules/
├── lifecycle/
│   ├── gastown-boot/       # Full town bootstrap
│   ├── rig-spinup/         # Add a rig at runtime
│   ├── rig-spindown/       # Remove a rig gracefully
│   └── agent-restart/      # Restart single agent
├── patrol/
│   ├── deacon-patrol/      # Deacon health loop
│   ├── witness-patrol/     # Witness polecat loop
│   └── refinery-patrol/    # Refinery merge loop
└── work/
    ├── polecat-work/       # Standard issue workflow
    ├── code-review/        # Pluggable review
    └── feature/            # Feature development
```

## mol-gastown-boot Structure

```
mol-gastown-boot (proto)
├── ensure-daemon       # Verify daemon running
├── ensure-deacon       # Start deacon, verify patrol active
├── ensure-witnesses    # Parallel: all rig witnesses
│   ├── ensure-gastown-witness
│   └── ensure-beads-witness
├── ensure-refineries   # Parallel: all rig refineries
│   ├── ensure-gastown-refinery
│   └── ensure-beads-refinery
└── verify-town-health  # Final gt status check
```

## Step Template

Each step in description includes action + verification:

```markdown
## Step: ensure-deacon

### Action
gt deacon start

### Verify
1. Session gt-deacon exists: `tmux has-session -t gt-deacon`
2. Not stalled: `gt peek deacon/` does NOT show "> Try"
3. Recent heartbeat: deacon/heartbeat.json < 2 min old

### On Stall
gt nudge deacon/ "Start patrol."
Wait 30s, re-verify.

### On Fail
Log error, continue to next step (town can run with degraded deacon)
```

## Event-Triggered Lifecycle

Beyond manual slinging, events can trigger lifecycle wisps:

| Event | Triggers |
|-------|----------|
| `gt town start` | mol-gastown-boot wisp |
| `gt rig add <name>` | mol-rig-spinup wisp |
| `gt rig remove <name>` | mol-rig-spindown wisp |
| Agent crash detected | mol-agent-restart wisp |

## Parameterization (Future)

For rig-spinup/spindown, need to pass rig name:

```bash
gt sling rig-spinup mayor/ --param rig=newproject
```

Molecule steps interpolate `${rig}` in their descriptions.

## Related Issues

- gt-lx3n: Witness startup bond
- gt-j6s8: Refinery startup bond  
- gt-rana: Patrol System epic
- gt-sye: Mayor startup protocol

title: Implement verification patterns for boot steps
description:
Define and implement the verification logic Mayor uses.

## Verification Utilities

Mayor needs to check:

### Session Exists
```bash
tmux has-session -t <session> 2>/dev/null && echo "exists"
```

### Not Stalled (Claude waiting at prompt)
```bash
gt peek <agent> 10 | grep -q "> Try" && echo "stalled"
```

Pattern: `> Try "..."` indicates Claude started but no message sent.

### Recent Heartbeat
```bash
# For deacon
age=$(( $(date +%s) - $(stat -f %m ~/gt/deacon/heartbeat.json) ))
[ $age -lt 120 ] && echo "fresh"
```

### Active Work Output
```bash
gt peek <agent> 20 | grep -q "⏺" && echo "working"
```

Pattern: `⏺` indicates Claude is executing tools.

## Mayor Execution Pattern

```
for each step in molecule:
  run action
  loop:
    check verification
    if verified: close step, continue
    if stalled: run on_stall recovery
    if timeout (5 attempts): log warning, continue
    sleep 10s
```

No hard timeout - Mayor keeps trying with increasing backoff.

title: Create molecules catalog directory structure
description:
Establish the proto catalog at ~/gt/molecules/.

## Structure

```
~/gt/molecules/
├── README.md           # Catalog overview
├── lifecycle/
│   ├── gastown-boot/
│   │   └── PROTO.md    # Proto definition in markdown
│   ├── rig-spinup/
│   ├── rig-spindown/
│   └── agent-restart/
├── patrol/
│   ├── deacon-patrol/
│   ├── witness-patrol/
│   └── refinery-patrol/
└── work/
    ├── polecat-work/
    ├── code-review/
    └── feature/
```

## PROTO.md Format

```markdown
---
type: lifecycle
parallel: [ensure-witnesses, ensure-refineries]
ephemeral: true
---

# mol-gastown-boot

Town bootstrap molecule.

## Step: ensure-daemon
...
```

## Catalog Loading

`gt sling gastown-boot` should find the proto by:
1. Check beads for existing proto issue
2. If not found, scan ~/gt/molecules/lifecycle/gastown-boot/
3. Auto-create proto issue from PROTO.md

This enables file-based proto development with beads tracking.

title: Add parallel step support to molecules
description:
Enable steps to run in parallel within a molecule.

## Current State

Molecules have linear step dependencies via "Needs:" directive.
Steps run sequentially.

## Proposed Change

Add parallel grouping:

```markdown
## Step: ensure-witnesses
Parallel: true

### Sub-steps
- ensure-gastown-witness
- ensure-beads-witness
```

Or via frontmatter:

```yaml
---
parallel: [ensure-witnesses, ensure-refineries]
---
```

Steps in parallel group:
- Start simultaneously
- Parent step closes when all children complete
- Failures in one dont block others

## Implementation

1. Parse parallel directive in proto
2. When bonding, create child steps with same dependency
3. Executor spawns parallel children concurrently
4. Track completion, close parent when all done

## For Mayor Bootstrap

Mayor can check all witnesses in parallel, then all refineries,
rather than sequentially. Faster boot time.

title: Add event-triggered lifecycle wisps
description:
Commands like `gt town start` should auto-trigger lifecycle wisps.

## Event → Wisp Mapping

| Command | Triggers Wisp |
|---------|---------------|
| gt town start | mol-gastown-boot |
| gt rig add <name> | mol-rig-spinup (param: rig=<name>) |
| gt rig remove <name> | mol-rig-spindown (param: rig=<name>) |
| gt daemon restart | mol-gastown-boot |

## Implementation

1. Command implementation checks for lifecycle proto
2. Auto-slings wisp to Mayor with --wisp flag
3. Mayor picks up via molecule attachment

## Alternative: Explicit Sling

Keep commands simple, require explicit:

```bash
gt town start        # Just starts sessions
gt sling gastown-boot mayor/ --wisp   # Bootstrap with verification
```

This is more transparent - user sees the sling happen.

## Recommendation

Start with explicit sling. Add auto-trigger later once pattern proven.
`gt town start --verified` could trigger the wisp.

title: Design molecule parameterization
description:
Enable protos to accept parameters for customization.

## Use Cases

1. rig-spinup needs rig name: `gt sling rig-spinup --param rig=newproject`
2. agent-restart needs agent: `gt sling agent-restart --param agent=gastown/witness`
3. code-review needs scope: `gt sling code-review --param scope=src/auth/`

## Proposed Syntax

### In Proto

```markdown
## Step: create-rig-structure
mkdir -p ~/gt/${rig}/refinery ~/gt/${rig}/witness
```

### In Sling

```bash
gt sling rig-spinup mayor/ --param rig=newproject --wisp
```

### In Bonded Molecule

Interpolation happens at bond time. Step descriptions have concrete values.

## Implementation

1. Proto declares params in frontmatter: `params: [rig]`
2. gt sling validates required params provided
3. bd mol bond receives params, interpolates descriptions
4. Bonded molecule has concrete step text

## Edge Cases

- Missing required param → error
- Unused param → warning
- Param in step title → interpolate there too

title: Update Mayor startup protocol for bootstrap
description:
Teach Mayor to respond to "boot up gas town" by slinging mol-gastown-boot.

## Current Protocol

1. Announce: "Mayor, checking in."
2. Check mail
3. If handoff, continue
4. Await user instruction

## Enhanced Protocol

1. Announce: "Mayor, checking in."
2. Check mail
3. If handoff, continue
4. **If user says "boot"/"startup"/"bootstrap":**
   - Sling mol-gastown-boot as wisp
   - Execute verification-gated steps
   - Report town status when complete
5. Otherwise await instruction

## Trigger Phrases

- "boot up gas town"
- "bootstrap the town"
- "start gas town"
- "bring up the town"

## Execution

Mayor runs the molecule manually (not via subagent):

```
1. Bond the proto: bd mol bond mol-gastown-boot --wisp
2. For each step:
   a. Run action command
   b. Loop verification with backoff
   c. On stall, run recovery
   d. Close step when verified
3. Squash wisp with summary
4. Report: "Gas Town is up. All agents healthy."
```

## CLAUDE.md Update

Add to Mayor CLAUDE.md:

```markdown
## Bootstrap Command

When user requests town bootstrap:
1. gt sling gastown-boot mayor/ --wisp
2. Execute molecule steps with verification
3. Keep trying until all agents healthy
4. No timeouts - you are the town engineer
```

title: gt crew add: role_bead field references non-existent bead
description:
## Problem

When `gt crew add` creates an agent bead (e.g., `gt-crew-gastown-grip`), it sets:
```
role_bead: gt-crew-gastown-grip-role
```

This is WRONG. It creates per-instance role bead references that don't exist.

## Correct Pattern

Role beads are SHARED templates defining what a role IS. Agent beads reference them:

| Role Type | Role Bead (shared) | Agent Bead (per-instance) |
|-----------|-------------------|---------------------------|
| Mayor | gt-mayor-role | gt-mayor |
| Deacon | gt-deacon-role | gt-deacon |
| Witness | gt-witness-role | gt-witness-<rig> |
| Refinery | gt-refinery-role | gt-refinery-<rig> |
| Crew | gt-crew-role | gt-crew-<rig>-<name> |
| Polecat | gt-polecat-role | gt-polecat-<rig>-<name> |

## Current State

Working correctly:
- gt-mayor → gt-mayor-role ✅
- gt-witness-gastown → gt-witness-role ✅
- gt-refinery-gastown → gt-refinery-role ✅

Broken:
- gt-deacon → gt-deacon-role (bead doesn't exist)
- gt-crew-* → gt-crew-<rig>-<name>-role (wrong pattern, beads don't exist)
- gt-polecat-* → (not set at all)

## Code Locations

1. `internal/cmd/crew_add.go:91` - sets `RoleBead: crewID + "-role"`
   Should be: `RoleBead: "gt-crew-role"`

2. `internal/polecat/manager.go:220,426` - doesn't set RoleBead
   Should set: `RoleBead: "gt-polecat-role"`

## Fix Required

1. Create missing role beads: gt-crew-role, gt-polecat-role, gt-deacon-role
2. Fix crew_add.go to use shared gt-crew-role
3. Fix polecat/manager.go to use shared gt-polecat-role
4. Update existing crew agent beads to point to gt-crew-role
close_reason: Fixed. Created shared role beads (gt-crew-role, gt-polecat-role, gt-deacon-role). Fixed code to reference shared role beads. Updated existing crew agent beads via bd slot set.

title: Cross-rig agent identity detection
description:
## Problem

Several gt commands fail to correctly detect agent identity when operating
across rigs. Running commands from beads/crew/dave shows gastown/crew/joe
identity, or fails to resolve paths.

## Root Cause

Agent identity detection in gt commands assumes single-rig context. Cross-rig
crew paths like `beads/crew/dave` are not handled correctly.

## Scope

- gt hook - shows wrong identity from other rig crew dir
- gt peek - fails to resolve cross-rig crew paths  
- gt sling - "." target not resolved to current agent

## Fix Strategy

Centralize agent identity detection to handle:
1. Current rig detection from cwd
2. Cross-rig path parsing (rig/crew/name vs rig/polecats/name)
3. "." resolution to current agent identity

- Deacon monitors Witnesses/Refineries
- Witnesses monitor Deacon (collectively)
- Mayor is escalation target for both

title: BUG: Cross-beads slot references silently fail
description:
When slinging work from town beads (hq-*) to a polecat whose agent bead is in rig beads (gt-*), the hook_bead update silently fails.

**Reproduction:**
```
# From mayor (town root):
gt sling hq-oosxt gastown/polecats/nux

# This runs (in updateAgentHookBead):
bd slot set gt-gastown-polecat-nux hook hq-oosxt
# FAILS: can't find hq-oosxt (different beads directory)
# Error is silently ignored!
```

**Result:**
- Agent bead keeps stale hook_bead value
- gt hook shows wrong/old work
- Agent doesn't know what they're actually assigned

**Root cause:**
sling.go line 812-814 silently ignores UpdateAgentState errors:
```go
if err := bd.UpdateAgentState(agentBeadID, "running", &beadID); err != nil {
    // Silently ignore - agent bead might not exist yet
    return
}
```

**Fix options:**
1. Log warnings instead of silent ignore
2. Support cross-beads slot references (store as 'hq-oosxt@town' or similar)
3. Use external: prefix for cross-beads hooks
4. Always store hook in the WORK bead's directory, not agent bead

Discovered during investigation of stale hook issue.
close_reason: Fixed: Use town root for routing in sling/done, log warnings instead of silent ignore

title: ZFC #9: Explicit MR registration instead of branch parsing
description:
**ZFC Violation:** internal/refinery/manager.go:346-370

Go infers work metadata from branch naming conventions:
```go
pattern := regexp.MustCompile(`^polecat/([^/]+)(?:/(.+))?$`)
worker := matches[1]
issueID = matches[2]
```

**ZFC-compliant solution:**
Polecats register MRs with explicit structured data:
- `gt mq submit --worker=nux --issue=gt-xyz --branch=polecat/nux/gt-xyz`
- Creates MR bead with explicit fields
- No regex parsing of branch names

**Benefits:**
- Work metadata is explicit, not inferred
- Branch naming can evolve without breaking refinery
- Audit trail in beads

Reference: ~/gt/docs/zfc-violations-audit.md #9

title: MEOW Stack Evolution: Higher-Order Workflow Abstractions
description:
Molecular Expression of Work (MEOW) - the full taxonomy of workflow abstractions.

## Current Hierarchy

```
WORK TRACKING              WORKFLOW EXECUTION
─────────────              ──────────────────

Bead (issue)               Step (action)
    │                          │
    ▼                          ▼
Epic (bead group)          Molecule (runtime)
    │                          │
    ▼                          │
    └───────► CAMPAIGN ◄───────┘
                  │
                  ▼
             Schematic (domain template)
                  │
                  ▼
             Protocol (interface/type)
                  │
                  ▼
             Catalyst (meta-generator)
                  │
                  ▼
             Mol Mall (distribution)
```

## Key Concepts

1. **Campaign** (gt-camx5): Molecule-wrapped Epic graph for orchestrated execution
2. **Schematic** (gt-8ws7o): Domain-level formula composition
3. **Protocol** (gt-y3jb9): Type system for formulas
4. **SDK** (gt-ihzqr): Developer tooling (Forge, Lab, Validator)
5. **Mol Mall** (gt-vm85o): Package registry for distribution

## Design Principles

- Chemistry metaphor: atoms → molecules → compounds → materials
- Two orthogonal dimensions: work tracking × workflow execution
- Campaign is the convergence point
- Everything compiles down to executable molecules

## Origin

Discussion: 2024-12-26, Mayor session
Related: docs/formula_evolution.md
Foundation: gt-8tmz (Molecule Algebra)

title: Polecat Role Definition
description:
You are a Polecat - an autonomous worker assigned to a specific issue.

You work independently, following the mol-polecat-work formula, and signal
completion to your Witness. You are transient - spawned for work, cleaned up
after completion.

session_pattern: gt-{rig}-{name}
work_dir_pattern: {town}/{rig}/polecats/{name}
needs_pre_sync: true
start_command: export GT_ROLE=polecat GT_RIG={rig} GT_POLECAT={name} BD_ACTOR={rig}/polecats/{name} && claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

default_molecule: mol-polecat-work
capabilities:
  - execute_assigned_work
  - git_operations
  - branch_management
  - completion_signaling

## Core Responsibilities

1. Execute your pinned molecule's steps
2. Maintain clean git state
3. Signal completion via gt done
4. Wait for Witness to handle lifecycle

## You Do NOT

- Push directly to main (Refinery merges)
- Kill your own session (Witness does cleanup)
- Skip verification steps
- Work on anything other than your assigned issue

## Propulsion Principle

If you find something on your hook, YOU RUN IT.

Your work is defined by your pinned molecule. Execute steps:
- bd ready (find next step)
- bd show <step-id> (see what to do)
- bd close <step-id> (mark complete)

## Completion Protocol

When done:
1. Tests pass: go test ./...
2. COMMIT changes: git add and git commit
3. Push branch: git push -u origin HEAD
4. Close issue: bd close <issue>
5. Sync beads: bd sync
6. Run gt done
7. WAIT: Witness will kill your session

## Communication

Mail your Witness when stuck:
gt mail send <rig>/witness -s "HELP: <problem>" -m "..."

title: mol-crew-session: Startup/shutdown protocols for crew workers
description:
Crew workers (like joe, max) don't have patrol molecules keeping them fresh. When gt gets rebuilt, they have stale binaries that cause hangs and bugs.

## Problem

- Crew binaries get stale when gt is rebuilt elsewhere
- No automatic pull/rebase/rebuild on session start
- No standardized shutdown protocol (sync, push, handoff)

## Solution: mol-crew-session

A molecule template for crew sessions:

### Startup Phase
1. `git pull --rebase` - get latest code
2. `bd sync` - sync beads
3. `go build -o gt ./cmd/gt` - rebuild gt (if in gastown)
4. `gt prime` - load context

### Work Phase  
- Open-ended human interaction
- No molecule steps - just work until done

### Shutdown Phase
1. `git status` - check for uncommitted changes
2. `bd sync` - sync beads
3. `git push` - push code
4. Handoff if incomplete work

## Implementation

1. Define mol-crew-session in builtin_molecules.go
2. Update crew CLAUDE.md to reference the protocol
3. Optionally: gt prime auto-runs startup steps

## Dependencies

- Should implement after deacon/witness/polecat patrols are stable
- Consider: gt-3x0z.10 (Witness patrol molecules)

## Related

- gt-3x0z.9: Deacon wisp patrol (done)
- fix-gt script: Current workaround for binary freshness

title: Simplify and reorganize molecular chemistry docs
description:
The Gas Town molecular chemistry docs (molecules.md, molecular-chemistry.md, molecule-algebra.md) are too dramatic and verbose. They need a simplification pass to be more reference-manual style.

**Current problems:**
1. Too much metaphor and philosophy, not enough practical reference
2. Start with the chemistry abstraction instead of what users care about (patrols, workflows)
3. Layer cake is presented top-down (formulas → protos → molecules) instead of bottom-up (issues → dependencies → execution)

**Proposed structure (inverted pyramid):**

1. **Start with execution semantics:**
   - Work = issues with dependencies
   - Dependencies control execution (blocks = sequential, no dep = parallel)
   - Agents traverse dependency graphs until blocked
   - Multi-day workflows via compound bonding

2. **Move to molecules:**
   - Molecules are just epics with workflow intent
   - Bonding = creating dependencies between work graphs
   - No protos required for ad-hoc workflows

3. **Then templates (protos/wisps):**
   - Phase metaphor for storage locations
   - pour/wisp/squash/burn operations
   - When to use each phase

4. **Finally formulas (for advanced users):**
   - YAML compile-time composition
   - extends, compose, aspects
   - Only needed for complex reusable patterns

**Style guidelines:**
- Reference manual with quick examples
- Written like agent priming (context they need to execute)
- Less dramatic, more straightforward
- TL;DR at top of each doc

**See also:**
- beads/docs/MOLECULES.md has a simplified version to use as template
- The execution model section explains multi-day traversal clearly

title: Session cycling UX: smooth transitions via TUI wrapper
description:
## Problem

Current CLI agent session cycling is painful:
- Shell → CC starts → priming → context loads → ready → work → exit/crash → repeat
- Each cycle is 30-60 seconds of cold boot
- No continuity between shell and agent's inner state
- Raw "session not running, starting..." loop is the baseline

## GGT Advantages (already have)

- Beads: Work state survives session death completely
- Mail: Handoff notes from past-self to future-self  
- Prime commands: Structured context reload

## Gap: Transition Mechanics

Ideas to explore when actively using CLI:

1. **In-band cycling** - `/restart` or `/cycle` command, agent handles own restart without dropping to shell

2. **Hot standby** - TUI maintains pre-warmed session in background, switch to already-primed agent

3. **Persistent wrapper** - Bubbletea TUI stays running across session cycles, CC sessions come/go inside it

4. **Session pooling** - Keep 2-3 primed sessions ready, never wait for cold start

## Deferred

Deliberately P4 until we're actively using the simpler CLI and feel the pain firsthand.

title: Refinery Role Definition
description:
You are the Refinery - merge queue processor for your rig. You process
completed polecat work, merging it to main one branch at a time with
sequential rebasing.

Your mission: Process the merge queue sequentially, rebasing each branch
atop the current baseline before merging.

session_pattern: gt-{rig}-refinery
work_dir_pattern: {town}/{rig}/refinery/rig
needs_pre_sync: true
start_command: exec claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

default_molecule: mol-refinery-patrol
capabilities:
  - merge_queue_processing
  - sequential_rebase
  - conflict_resolution
  - verification_gates

## The Engineer Mindset

You are Scotty in the engine room. The merge queue is your warp core.

The Beads Promise: Work is never lost. If you discover ANY problem:
1. Fix it now (preferred if quick), OR
2. File a bead and proceed (tracked for cleanup crew)

There is NO third option. Never "disavow" by noting something exists and moving on.

The Scotty Test: Before proceeding past any failure, ask yourself:
"Would Scotty walk past a warp core leak because it existed before his shift?"

## Propulsion Principle

If you find something on your hook, YOU RUN IT.

Your work is defined by the mol-refinery-patrol molecule. Execute steps:
- bd ready (find next step)
- bd show <step-id> (see what to do)
- bd close <step-id> (mark complete)

## Sequential Rebase Protocol

WRONG (parallel merge - causes conflicts):
  main then branch-A (old main) + branch-B (old main) = CONFLICTS

RIGHT (sequential rebase):
  main then merge A (rebased on main) then merge B (rebased on main+A)

After every merge, main moves. Next branch MUST rebase on new baseline.

## Verification Gate

The handle-failures step is a verification gate:
- Tests PASSED: Gate satisfied, proceed to merge
- Tests FAILED (branch caused): Abort, notify polecat, skip branch
- Tests FAILED (pre-existing): MUST fix OR file bead - cannot proceed without

## Commands

### Patrol
- gt mol status - Check attached patrol
- bd ready / bd show / bd close - Step management
- bd mol spawn <mol> --wisp - Spawn patrol wisp

title: Exponential backoff for idle patrol agents
description:
## Problem

Patrol agents (Refinery, Witness, Deacon) currently have no backoff when their queue is empty. They either:
- Loop immediately (wasting cycles)
- Exit and wait for 10-minute daemon respawn (too slow to respond)

## Solution: Feed-Driven Backoff

### The Pattern (from PRIMING.md)

> "Backoff isn't about polling less - it's about **waiting for signals with a timeout**."

Agents subscribe to `bd activity --follow` and wake on any beads mutation. The timeout increases exponentially during idle periods.

### Data Flow

```
bd/gt mutations → .events.jsonl → feed curator → .feed.jsonl
                                                      ↓
                    patrol agent: gt mol await-signal --backoff-*
                                                      ↓
                              signal → wake, reset idle_cycles
                              timeout → increment idle_cycles, sleep longer
```

### Backoff Formula

```
timeout = min(base × multiplier^idle_cycles, max)
```

| Idle Cycles | Timeout |
|-------------|---------|
| 0 | 30s |
| 1 | 1m |
| 2 | 2m |
| 3 | 4m |
| 4+ | 5m (capped) |

### Agent State Storage

Operational state stored as labels on agent beads (labels-as-cache pattern):
- `idle:3` - consecutive idle patrol cycles
- `backoff:2m` - current backoff interval (derived)
- `last_activity:2025-12-31T10:00:00Z` - timestamp

### Implementation Layers

**Layer 1: gt agent state command**
```bash
gt agent state <agent-bead>                    # Get labels
gt agent state <agent-bead> --set idle=0       # Set label
gt agent state <agent-bead> --incr idle        # Increment
```

**Layer 2: Fix await-signal iteration tracking**
- Read `idle:N` label from agent bead
- Calculate effective timeout using BackoffConfig
- On timeout: increment label, return "timeout"
- On signal: return "signal" (agent resets)

**Layer 3: Patrol formula integration**
Update burn-or-loop step:
```bash
# If work found
gt agent state $AGENT_BEAD --set idle=0

# If no work
gt mol await-signal --agent-bead $AGENT_BEAD   --backoff-base 30s --backoff-mult 2 --backoff-max 5m

# After 10 consecutive max-timeout cycles, exit for fresh session
```

**Layer 4: Feed signal sources**
Ensure these emit events:
- gt sling → TypeSling
- bd create/update/close → BeadMutation
- gt mail send → TypeMail

### ZFC Compliance

| Component | Role | ZFC |
|-----------|------|-----|
| Feed curator | Aggregates events | ✅ Transport |
| await-signal | Waits with timeout | ✅ Transport |
| Agent bead labels | Stores idle_cycles | ✅ Agent-written |
| Backoff decision | Agent decides | ✅ Agent decides |

Go code provides mechanics. **Agent decides** parameters, reset, and exit.

### Existing Infrastructure

- Feed Curator: internal/feed/curator.go ✅
- BackoffConfig: internal/beads/molecule.go ✅
- await-signal cmd: internal/cmd/molecule_await_signal.go (needs fix)
- Agent Beads: internal/beads/beads.go ✅
- Labels pattern: docs/operational-state.md ✅

### Exit Strategy

After N consecutive max-interval cycles (e.g., 10 × 5m = 50 minutes idle):
- Agent exits cleanly
- Daemon respawns fresh session
- Fresh session starts with idle:0

- Each step checks if already done before doing

title: Design: Polecat lifecycle and patrol coordination
description:
## Context

This design captures thinking from a deep session about the Gas Town propulsion system - how Deacon, Witness, Refinery, and Polecats coordinate to move work smoothly through the system.

## Core Insight: Session-Per-Step Model

Polecats do NOT complete complex molecules end-to-end. Instead:
- One polecat SESSION per molecule STEP
- Same sandbox (branch/worktree) persists across sessions
- Each step: spawn → work → close bead → recycle session
- Final step: spawn → work → close bead → signal complete → merge → nuke sandbox

## Two Cleanup Stages

| Stage | Trigger | Kills | Survives |
|-------|---------|-------|----------|
| Step cleanup | Step bead closed | Session | Branch, worktree, molecule |
| Molecule cleanup | Merged | Session, branch, worktree | Digest |

## Per-Rig Polecat Channel

Need a mailing list/queue per rig for session-lifecycle requests:
- "Recycle me" (from polecat)
- "Recycle worker X" (from witness/mayor)
- "Spawn for step Y" (from anyone)

First-come-first-served by patrolling agents. Anyone on patrol (Witness, Refinery, Crew, Mayor) can service requests.

## GUPP + Pinned Work = Completion

As long as:
1. Work is pinned to polecat identity (e.g., gastown/furiosa)
2. Sandbox persists (branch + worktree)
3. Someone keeps spawning polecat when it dies

→ The molecule WILL get finished. GUPP ensures wake-and-work.

## Daemon → Deacon Heartbeat

The daemon pings the deacon, keeping the cycle alive. Deacon peeks into rig-wide channels during patrol and can service lifecycle requests.

## Open Design Questions

### Q1: Spoon-Feeding Bin-Packing
Two dimensions of granularity trade-offs:
- How many logical steps per physical molecule step?
- How many molecule steps per polecat session?

Too few steps → context exhaustion, forgetting
Too many steps → overhead, fragmentation

Needs: Analysis of optimal granularity based on step complexity.

### Q2: Mechanical vs Agent-Driven Recycling
Caution from deacon murder spree bug: mechanical detection of "stuck" workers is fragile.

Prefer: Explicit "recycle me" requests serviced by patrol agents.

Question: When is mechanical intervention appropriate?

### Q3: Channel Implementation
Options:
- Mail-based (gt mail to rig/polecats)
- Beads-based (special issue type)
- State file (rig/polecat-queue.json)

Mail seems most consistent with Gas Town patterns.

### Q4: Who Spawns Next Step?
Current: gt sling spawns fresh polecat
Needed: Mechanism for "continue molecule on existing sandbox"

Maybe: gt sling --continue or witness detects pending step.

## Related Issues

- gt-dtw9u: Witness monitoring (enhance survey-workers)
- gt-qpwv4: Completion detection (check ready branches)
- gt-6qyt1: Refinery queue (process MERGE_READY)
- gt-budeb: Auto-nuke (handle MERGED signal)
- gt-5j3ia: Swarm aggregation (batch completion)
- gt-1dbcp: Polecat auto-start (SessionStart hook issue)

## Design Principles (from HOP/MEOW context)

1. **Discovery over tracking** - observe reality each cycle
2. **Mail as coordination primitive** - agents signal via mail
3. **ZFC** - Claude makes judgment calls, no hardcoded thresholds
4. **Redundant monitoring** - overlapping observation is resilience
5. **Wisps are ephemeral** - patrol molecules flow like water

## Next Steps

1. Finalize channel design (mail-based queue)
2. Enhance witness patrol formula with completion detection
3. Enhance refinery patrol with MERGED signaling
4. Implement step-level recycling
5. Design spoon-feeding granularity guidelines

title: queue: shared storage work queues
description:
## queue: Shared Storage Work Queues

Work queue with shared storage (single copy, first-to-claim).

## Pattern Clarification

**Queue is a MAILBOX pattern** (pull-based):
- Workers poll shared queue
- First to claim gets the work
- Worker decides when to check

**This is DIFFERENT from Dog dispatch** (push-based):
- `gt sling <work> deacon/dogs` pushes to hook
- GUPP fires immediately
- Deacon decides when to assign

| Pattern | Mechanism | Initiative |
|---------|-----------|------------|
| `queue:` | Poll mailbox, claim | Worker pulls |
| Dog sling | Hook assignment | Deacon pushes |

## Use Cases for queue:

1. **Batch cleanup tasks** - Multiple agents can help, order does not matter
2. **Overflow work** - When primary handler is busy
3. **Opportunistic tasks** - Agents check between other work

## Deliverables

1. Parse queue:name syntax in router
2. Shared storage model:
   - Single message copy (NOT fan-out)
   - Stored in queue-specific location
   - Multiple agents can see it
3. Queue configuration in ~/gt/config/queues.json
4. Queue inbox command: gt mail queue <name>
5. Claim semantics: `gt mail claim <msg-id>` marks as claimed

## Key Difference from list:
- list: creates N copies (N obligations)
- queue: creates 1 copy (1 obligation, first-to-claim)

## Dependencies
- Config directory (gt-i6jvc) ✅ closed

## Acceptance
- queue:cleanup creates single message
- Multiple agents can view queue
- Claim marks message as taken
- Message invisible to others after claim

title: MQ smart scheduling: dependency-aware queue reordering
description:
Implement intelligent MQ reordering to minimize conflicts.

## Goal
Reorder the MQ so that MRs touching disjoint files merge "in parallel" (no conflicts), while MRs touching overlapping files are sequenced.

## Approach
1. For each MR, get list of changed files (from branch diff)
2. Build conflict graph: edge between MRs if files overlap
3. Find maximal independent sets (MRs that can merge in any order)
4. Schedule independent MRs first, then handle remaining sequentially

## Implementation
- Add file analysis to MR submission (gt done)
- Store changed_files in MR wisp
- Refinery sorts queue by: priority → conflicts → age

## Example
```
Queue: [A, B, C, D]
Files:
  A: auth/login.go
  B: payments/checkout.go  
  C: auth/login.go ← conflicts with A!
  D: docs/readme.md

Optimal: [A, B, D, C] - A, B, D can merge without waiting
```

title: Plugin system: subprocess JSON protocol
description:
Language-agnostic plugin system via subprocess JSON protocol.

## Concept

Allow extending Gas Town with external scripts/programs. Plugins communicate via stdin/stdout JSON.

## Protocol

Request (gt → plugin):
```json
{"method": "check", "params": {"rig": "wyvern", "polecat": "Toast"}}
```

Response (plugin → gt):
```json
{"result": {...}, "error": null}
```

Error response:
```json
{"result": null, "error": {"code": 1, "message": "..."}}
```

## Interface

```go
type Plugin struct {
    Name    string
    Path    string  // executable path
    Methods []string
}

type PluginManager struct {
    plugins map[string]*Plugin
}

func NewPluginManager() *PluginManager
func (pm *PluginManager) Register(plugin *Plugin) error
func (pm *PluginManager) Call(plugin, method string, params any) (any, error)
func (pm *PluginManager) Discover(dir string) error  // auto-discover plugins
```

## Plugin Discovery

Look in:
1. `<town>/plugins/`
2. `~/.config/gastown/plugins/`
3. System path with `gt-plugin-*` prefix

## Built-in Hooks

Plugins can register for events:
- `polecat.started` - Polecat session started
- `polecat.done` - Polecat signals done
- `merge.requested` - MR submitted
- `merge.completed` - MR merged

## Use Cases

- Custom health checks
- Integration with external systems (Slack, etc.)
- Custom merge policies
- Metrics collection

## Future

Consider MCP integration for richer plugin capabilities.

title: Formula Molecules: Guzzoline production for Gas Town
description:
## Vision

Gas Town executes work. But it also needs to PRODUCE work - structured, high-quality guzzoline on demand. **Formula Molecules** are recipes that spawn structured convoys.

## Core Insight

A formula is a molecule template that:
1. Takes input (a PR, a design problem, a codebase)
2. Spawns multiple polecats with specific focuses
3. Each leg produces structured output
4. Synthesis step combines into unified deliverable

Gas Town becomes both consumer AND producer of guzzoline.

## Example Formulas

### Design Convoy Formula
Input: Feature request or problem statement
Legs (parallel):
- API design polecat
- Data model polecat  
- UX/ergonomics polecat
- Scalability polecat
- Security polecat
Synthesis: Unified design doc with tradeoffs

### Code Review Convoy Formula
Input: PR or file set
Legs (parallel):
- Correctness: Does it work?
- Performance: Any bottlenecks?
- Security: Vulnerabilities?
- Elegance: Clean design?
- Resilience: Error handling?
- Style: Convention compliance?
- Smells: Anti-patterns?
- Legacy: Respects existing patterns?
Synthesis: Categorized review with priority issues

### Other Formula Ideas
- Test Coverage Convoy: Unit, integration, edge cases, error paths
- Documentation Convoy: API docs, user guide, examples, changelog
- Migration Convoy: Database, API, config, rollback plan
- Incident Response: Root cause, timeline, fix, prevention

## Mol Mall

Library/marketplace of formulas:
```bash
gt formula list              # Available formulas
gt formula show code-review  # Formula details
gt formula run code-review --pr=123  # Execute formula → convoy
gt formula create my-review  # Create custom formula
```

## Technical Design

### Formula Structure (in beads)
```yaml
id: formula-code-review
type: formula
name: Code Review
inputs:
  - name: target
    type: pr | files | branch
legs:
  - name: correctness
    focus: "Verify logical correctness and edge cases"
    output: findings.md
  - name: security
    focus: "Identify security vulnerabilities"
    output: findings.md
  # ...
synthesis:
  inputs: all leg outputs
  output: review-summary.md
```

### Execution Model
1. `gt formula run` creates convoy with formula reference
2. Spawns polecats for each leg (parallel where possible)
3. Each polecat gets leg-specific prompt + shared context
4. Outputs collected as bead attachments or slots
5. Synthesis polecat reads all outputs, produces final deliverable
6. Convoy lands with unified result

### Dependencies
- Leg outputs feed synthesis (internal convoy deps)
- Formula can specify leg ordering if needed
- Parallel by default, sequential where required

## Open Questions

1. Where do formulas live? Town-level beads? Separate formula registry?
2. How to version/share formulas across towns?
3. Leg output format standardization?
4. Human checkpoints between legs or only at end?
5. Partial formula runs (skip some legs)?
6. Formula composition (formula that includes other formulas)?

## Why This Matters

Gas Town currently waits for humans to create work. With formulas:
- Mayor can invoke structured reviews on any PR
- Design work follows consistent methodology
- Quality processes are repeatable and scalable
- Work generation becomes as automated as work execution

**Guzzoline factory, not just guzzoline consumer.**

title: Patrol exponential backoff for cost savings
description:
Agent-side backoff state tracking in patrol molecules.

## State

Each patrol agent tracks:
- current_interval: current sleep duration (starts at base)
- idle_cycles: count of cycles with no work found

## Backoff Logic

```
on await-signal timeout (no nudge):
    idle_cycles++
    current_interval = min(base * 2^idle_cycles, max_interval)

on nudge received:
    idle_cycles = 0
    current_interval = base
    wake immediately

on work found:
    idle_cycles = 0
    current_interval = base
```

## Where State Lives

Options:
A. Agent bead fields (persistent across sessions)
B. In-memory during patrol (resets on restart)
C. Wisp fields (ephemeral but survives handoff)

Option B is simplest - backoff resets when agent restarts anyway.

## Depends On

- gt-l6ro3.3: await-signal step type

title: Verify commit on main before nuke (not just MERGED signal)
description:
Witness nukes on MERGED signal without verifying merge actually succeeded.

## Problem
MERGED signal means refinery ATTEMPTED merge. But:
- Merge could have failed after signal sent
- Merge could be to wrong branch
- MERGED could be for stale MR (already merged via different path)

## Fix
Before nuke, witness should verify:
```bash
# Get the commit SHA from the polecat branch
commit_sha=$(git rev-parse polecat/$name)

# Verify it's reachable from main
git merge-base --is-ancestor $commit_sha main
```

Only nuke if verification passes.

## Alternative
Refinery sends commit SHA in MERGED payload, witness verifies that specific SHA.

title: Feed-Based Wake Model for Patrol Agents
description:
## The Paradigm Shift

> **Backoff is not about polling less. It is about waiting for signals with a timeout.**

This epic captures the shift from time-driven to event-driven patrol wake.

## Key Insight (Recovered from 2025-12-29 session crash)

The Beads activity feed (bd activity --follow) is the universal data plane for
wake signals. Every meaningful action creates a beads mutation; agents subscribe to
the feed and wake within ~500ms. The timeout is just a safety net.

**OLD**: Time-driven. Wake because time passed. Poll less when idle.
**NEW**: Event-driven. Wake because signal arrived. Timeout is safety net.

## Architecture

ANY MUTATION:
  bd create/update/close -> issues.jsonl mutation
                        -> bd activity --follow sees it (~500ms)
                        -> All subscribed agents wake immediately

PATROL AGENT:
  Runs bd activity --follow as background source
  Any output line = wake signal
  Timeout expiry = safety net (not primary wake)

## Wake Sources (Priority Order)

| Source | Latency | Purpose |
|--------|---------|---------|
| Feed | ~500ms | Primary - any beads mutation |
| Nudge | Instant | Explicit wake (startup hooks) |
| Timeout | Backoff | Safety net for missed signals |
| Daemon | 5-60min | GUPP backstop, session recovery |

## Key Design Decisions

1. No wake_on conditions - signals carry no semantic meaning. Just wake up.
   Agent discovers reality by checking mail, beads, hook, git state.

2. Read-only commands do not wake - gt status, bd show create no mutations.

3. Daemon is recovery-focused - catches edge cases (GUPP violations, dead sessions).

4. Keepalive file deprecated - the feed replaces the keepalive mechanism.

## Reference

- ~/gt/docs/patrol-system-design.md (Sleeping Agents section)
- ~/gt/docs/PRIMING.md (Feed Is the Signal insight)

## Related

- gt-l6ro3: Patrol Exponential Backoff System (backoff timing, complements this)

title: Mol Mall: Formula Package Registry
description:
A package registry for sharing and discovering formulas, schematics, and protocols.

## Concept

Like npm/Maven/Go modules but for workflow definitions.

```
mol-mall.io/
├── @gastown/           # Official Gas Town formulas
│   ├── shiny
│   ├── polecat-work
│   └── release
├── @acme-corp/         # Enterprise org (private)
│   └── compliance-review
├── @linus/             # Individual publisher
│   └── kernel-review
└── community/          # Unscoped public formulas
    └── towers-of-hanoi
```

## Resolution Hierarchy

```
1. Project:  ./.beads/formulas/          # Project-specific
2. Rig:      ~/gt/<rig>/.formulas/       # Rig-wide
3. Town:     ~/gt/.formulas/             # Town-wide (mayor stdlib)
4. User:     ~/.gastown/formulas/        # Personal collection
5. Mall:     mol-mall.io/                # Published packages
```

## Package Manifest

```toml
[package]
name = "shiny"
version = "1.2.0"
description = "Engineer in a Box"
authors = ["Gas Town <gastown@example.com>"]
license = "MIT"

[dependencies]
"@gastown/review-patterns" = "^2.0"
```

## Distribution Scenarios

1. **Celebrity Formulas**: Expert-curated workflows (e.g., Linus kernel review)
2. **Enterprise Compliance**: Private company formulas
3. **Standard Library**: @gastown/* blessed defaults
4. **Community Ecosystem**: Varying quality, needs ratings/verification

## Open Questions

1. Versioning semantics - SemVer? Breaking change rules?
2. Security model - sandboxing? signing? permissions?
3. Private registries - self-hosted? authentication?
4. Lock files - formulas.lock format?

## Related

- docs/formula_evolution.md - package ecosystem parallel section
- gt-8ws7o - Schematic (can be published)
- gt-y3jb9 - Protocol (can be published)

title: Check own context limit
description:
Check own context limit.

The Deacon runs in a Claude session with finite context. Check if approaching the limit:

```bash
gt context --usage
```

If context is high (>80%), prepare for handoff:
- Summarize current state
- Note any pending work
- Write handoff to molecule state

This enables the Deacon to burn and respawn cleanly.

title: Evaluate pending async gates
description:
Evaluate pending async gates.

Gates are async coordination primitives that block until conditions are met.
The Deacon is responsible for monitoring gates and closing them when ready.

**Timer gates** (await_type: timer):
Check if elapsed time since creation exceeds the timeout duration.

```bash
# List all open gates
bd gate list --json

# For each timer gate, check if elapsed:
# - CreatedAt + Timeout < Now → gate is ready to close
# - Close with: bd gate close <id> --reason "Timer elapsed"
```

**GitHub gates** (await_type: gh:run, gh:pr) - handled in separate step.

**Human/Mail gates** - require external input, skip here.

After closing a gate, the Waiters field contains mail addresses to notify.
Send a brief notification to each waiter that the gate has cleared.

title: Execute registered plugins
description:
Execute registered plugins.

Scan ~/gt/plugins/ for plugin directories. Each plugin has a plugin.md with YAML frontmatter defining its gate (when to run) and instructions (what to do).

See docs/deacon-plugins.md for full documentation.

Gate types:
- cooldown: Time since last run (e.g., 24h)
- cron: Schedule-based (e.g., "0 9 * * *")
- condition: Metric threshold (e.g., wisp count > 50)
- event: Trigger-based (e.g., startup, heartbeat)

For each plugin:
1. Read plugin.md frontmatter to check gate
2. Compare against state.json (last run, etc.)
3. If gate is open, execute the plugin

Plugins marked parallel: true can run concurrently using Task tool subagents. Sequential plugins run one at a time in directory order.

Skip this step if ~/gt/plugins/ does not exist or is empty.

title: Burn and respawn or loop
description:
Burn and let daemon respawn, or exit if context high.

Decision point at end of patrol cycle:

If context is LOW:
- Sleep briefly (avoid tight loop)
- Return to inbox-check step

If context is HIGH:
- Write state to persistent storage
- Exit cleanly
- Let the daemon orchestrator respawn a fresh Deacon

The daemon ensures Deacon is always running:
```bash
# Daemon respawns on exit
gt daemon status
```

This enables infinite patrol duration via context-aware respawning.

title: Clean dead sessions
description:
Clean dead sessions and orphaned state.

Run `gt doctor --fix` to handle all cleanup:

```bash
# Preview what needs cleaning
gt doctor -v

# Fix everything
gt doctor --fix
```

This handles:
- **orphan-sessions**: Kill orphaned tmux sessions (gt-* not matching valid patterns)
- **orphan-processes**: Kill orphaned Claude processes (no tmux parent)
- **wisp-gc**: Garbage collect abandoned wisps (>1h old)

All cleanup is handled by doctor checks - no need to run separate commands.

title: Find abandoned work
description:
Find abandoned work.

Scan for orphaned state:
- Issues marked in_progress with no active polecat
- Polecats that stopped responding mid-work
- Merge queue entries with no polecat owner
- Wisp sessions that outlived their spawner

```bash
bd list --status=in_progress
gt polecats --all --orphan
```

For each orphan:
- Check if polecat session still exists
- If not, mark issue for reassignment or retry
- File incident beads if data loss occurred

title: Check Witness and Refinery health
description:
Check Witness and Refinery health for each rig.

**ZFC Principle**: You (Claude) make the judgment call about what is "stuck" or "unresponsive" - there are no hardcoded thresholds in Go. Read the signals, consider context, and decide.

For each rig, run:
```bash
gt witness status <rig>
gt refinery status <rig>
```

**Signals to assess:**

| Component | Healthy Signals | Concerning Signals |
|-----------|-----------------|-------------------|
| Witness | State: running, recent activity | State: not running, no heartbeat |
| Refinery | State: running, queue processing | Queue stuck, merge failures |

**Tracking unresponsive cycles:**

Maintain in your patrol state (persisted across cycles):
```
health_state:
  <rig>:
    witness:
      unresponsive_cycles: 0
      last_seen_healthy: <timestamp>
    refinery:
      unresponsive_cycles: 0
      last_seen_healthy: <timestamp>
```

**Decision matrix** (you decide the thresholds based on context):

| Cycles Unresponsive | Suggested Action |
|---------------------|------------------|
| 1-2 | Note it, check again next cycle |
| 3-4 | Attempt restart: gt witness restart <rig> |
| 5+ | Escalate to Mayor with context |

**Restart commands:**
```bash
gt witness restart <rig>
gt refinery restart <rig>
```

**Escalation:**
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Health: <rig> <component> unresponsive" \
  -m "Component has been unresponsive for N cycles. Restart attempts failed.
      Last healthy: <timestamp>
      Error signals: <details>"
```

Reset unresponsive_cycles to 0 when component responds normally.

title: Nudge newly spawned polecats
description:
Nudge newly spawned polecats that are ready for input.

When polecats are spawned, their Claude session takes 10-20 seconds to initialize. The spawn command returns immediately without waiting. This step finds spawned polecats that are now ready and sends them a trigger to start working.

**ZFC-Compliant Observation** (AI observes AI):

```bash
# View pending spawns with captured terminal output
gt deacon pending
```

For each pending session, analyze the captured output:
- Look for Claude's prompt indicator "> " at the start of a line
- If prompt is visible, Claude is ready for input
- Make the judgment call yourself - you're the AI observer

For each ready polecat:
```bash
# 1. Trigger the polecat
gt nudge <session> "Begin."

# 2. Clear from pending list
gt deacon pending <session>
```

This triggers the UserPromptSubmit hook, which injects mail so the polecat sees its assignment.

**Bootstrap mode** (daemon-only, no AI available):
The daemon uses `gt deacon trigger-pending` with regex detection. This ZFC violation is acceptable during cold startup when no AI agent is running yet.

title: mol-deacon-patrol

Mayor's daemon patrol loop.

The Deacon is the Mayor's background process that runs continuously, handling callbacks, monitoring rig health, and performing cleanup. Each patrol cycle runs these steps in sequence, then loops or exits.

title: mol-witness-patrol
description:
Per-rig worker monitor patrol loop using the Christmas Ornament pattern.

The Witness is the Pit Boss for your rig. You watch polecats, nudge them toward
completion, verify clean git state before kills, and escalate stuck workers.

**You do NOT do implementation work.** Your job is oversight, not coding.

This molecule uses dynamic bonding to spawn mol-polecat-arm for each worker,
enabling parallel inspection with a fanout gate for aggregation.

## The Christmas Ornament Shape

```
                     ★ mol-witness-patrol (trunk)
                    /|\
          ┌────────┘ │ └────────┐
       PREFLIGHT  DISCOVERY  CLEANUP
          │          │           │
      inbox-check  survey    aggregate (WaitsFor: all-children)
      check-refnry   │       save-state
      load-state     │       generate-summary
                     ↓       context-check
             ┌───────┼───────┐  burn-or-loop
             ●       ●       ●   mol-polecat-arm (dynamic)
            ace     nux    toast
```

- Witnesses reporting polecat status
- Refineries reporting merge results
- Polecats requesting help or escalation
- External triggers (webhooks, timers)

```bash

# For each message:
gt mail read <id>
# Handle based on message type
```

Callbacks may spawn new polecats, update issue state, or trigger other actions.

title: Witness Role Definition
description:
You are the Witness - per-rig worker monitor. You watch polecats, nudge them
toward completion, verify clean git state before kills, and escalate stuck
workers to the Mayor.

You do NOT do implementation work. Your job is oversight, not coding.

session_pattern: gt-{rig}-witness
work_dir_pattern: {town}/{rig}
needs_pre_sync: false
start_command: exec claude --dangerously-skip-permissions

default_molecule: mol-witness-patrol
capabilities:
  - monitor_workers
  - nudge_stuck
  - pre_kill_verify
  - session_lifecycle
  - escalation

## Core Responsibilities

1. Monitor workers: Track polecat health and progress
2. Nudge: Prompt slow workers toward completion
3. Pre-kill verification: Ensure git state is clean before killing sessions
4. Session lifecycle: Kill sessions, update worker state
5. Self-cycling: Hand off to fresh session when context fills
6. Escalation: Report stuck workers to Mayor

Key principle: You own ALL per-worker cleanup. Mayor is never involved in
routine worker management.

## Propulsion Principle

If you find something on your hook, YOU RUN IT.

Your work is defined by the mol-witness-patrol molecule. Execute steps:
- bd ready (find next step)
- bd show <step-id> (see what to do)
- bd close <step-id> (mark complete)

## Nudge Protocol

Progress through stages. Track nudge count per worker per issue.
- First Nudge (10+ min idle): Gentle inquiry
- Second Nudge (15 min): Direct question
- Third Nudge (20 min): Final warning
After 3 nudges with no progress then escalate to Mayor

## Pre-Kill Verification

Before killing ANY polecat session:
1. gt polecat git-state <name> - Must be clean
2. Check for uncommitted work
3. Check for unpushed commits
4. Verify issue closed
5. Verify PR submitted (if applicable)

## Commands

- gt polecat list <rig> - See all polecats
- gt polecat git-state <name> - Check git cleanliness
- tmux capture-pane -t gt-<rig>-<name> -p | tail -40 - Session inspection
- gt mail inbox - Check messages
- gt mail send mayor/ -s "Subject" -m "Message" - Escalate

title: Use atomic write pattern for state files
description:
attached_args: Atomic write pattern for state files

Prevent data loss from concurrent state file writes using atomic write pattern.

## Files to modify
- internal/witness/manager.go
- internal/refinery/manager.go
- internal/crew/manager.go
- internal/swarm/manager.go

## Problem
State is saved directly to file - if process crashes mid-write, file corrupts.

## Implementation
Replace direct writes with atomic pattern:
```go
func atomicWriteJSON(path string, v interface{}) error {
    data, err := json.MarshalIndent(v, "", "  ")
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }
    tmpFile := path + ".tmp"
    if err := os.WriteFile(tmpFile, data, 0644); err != nil {
        return err
    }
    return os.Rename(tmpFile, path)  // Atomic on POSIX
}
```

## Acceptance criteria
- [ ] atomicWriteJSON helper created (in internal/util or similar)
- [ ] All 4 manager saveState methods use atomic writes
- [ ] .tmp files cleaned up on success
- [ ] go test ./... passes
- [ ] Manual test: state files survive kill -9

Convoys are now the most important unit of work for certain Gas Town users.
The convoy-landing feed is THE view of feature work and fixes actually shipping.

gt feed shows:
- Agent tree (top panel): agents by role

┌─🚚 Convoys─────────────────────────────┐
